page.title: 03LOCAL HISTORY IN LIPHOOK
page.content: Bramshott for a long time was more important than Liphook.Saxons prefered to travel by the river so they stayed at Bramshott because of the River Wey. Britain's sea trade increased over years,so the land route between the trade centre of London and Portsmouth which grew with importance. Liphook was then used for stopping places for horses. Most coaches stopped at the Anchor Inn but some stopped at the "Wheatsheaf"now called 'the Links.' This was an important route, travelled by important people.Edward II stayed in the Anchor around 1320. Edward IV, the wife of George III and Queen Victoria also stayed there. Nelson stayed at the Anchor on his way to Trafalgar and the Duke of Wellington had dinner there on the
